Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Neutron Interferometry Experiments in Nuclear Physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
A neutron interferometer splits the wave function of a free neutron into two coherent beams by Bragg diffraction in a single silicon crystal. The relative phase shift caused by different path lengths, potentials, or materials in the beams produces interference fringes in one or more neutron counters. This phase can be measured within a fraction of a degree in an interferogram so the neutron interaction potential in the sample can be determined to high precision. This program is focused on using neutron interferometry to make precision neutron scattering length measurements of importance to nuclear physics. The neutron interferometer measures a phase shift so it has direct access to the scattering length. This is a fruitful and often more precise alternative to nuclear scattering experiments which measure a cross section (a product of scattering lengths). For example, in a cross section measurement one is limited by uncertainty of the incident neutron flux; in a phase shift measurement that is not important. Experiments include precision measurement of few body neutron scattering lengths, important for improving our understanding of the nucleon-nucleon potential through semi-phenomenological models and effective field theories; and a precision measurement of the neutron mean-squared charge radius, an important quantity for understanding the internal structure and dynamics of the neutron.

According to the theory of quantum mechanics, all matter becomes wave-like when it moves very slowly. Matter waves exhibit wave properties such as diffraction and refraction that are normally associated with light waves. A neutron interferometer uses neutron matter-wave diffraction in a silicon crystal to split a slow neutron beam into two distinct paths. By placing a test sample into one of these paths, and observing the resulting wave interference, we can precisely measure the interaction of the neutron beam with the sample. Such measurements are used to improve our understanding of the physical forces between neutrons and matter, and of the fundamental sub-structure of matter itself.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A neutron interferometer is a device that uses the wave-matter duality of nature to make very precise measurements of the interaction between free neutrons and matter. According to quantum mechanics, all particles of matter possess wave properties that become most apparent when very small particles move very slowly. In particular, slow neutrons (traveling about 2000 meters per second) that we employ have a quantum mechanical (de Broglie) wavelength of 0.235 nanometers, much larger than the neutron's physical diameter and comparable in size to the spacing of atoms in a solid or liquid. Therefore a cold neutron behaves like a wave when it interacts with a solid crystal of silicon and we can split the neutron wave by diffraction into two paths that are separated by several centimeters. In other words, quantum mechanics allows us to place a single neutron in two places at once! One of these wave paths is allowed to pass through a sample target. When the two wave paths are recombined they form an interference pattern, much like ripples in a pond, from which we extract precise information about the neutron-target interaction.

 

The focus of this project was to measure the neutron scattering length (a measure of the strength of the scattering interaction) between a neutron and the nucleus of a light atom such as helium. This scattering length is an important parameter for theorists who are trying to better understand the nature of the nuclear strong force at low energy. We used the rare isotope helium-3, whose nucleus contains two protons and one neutron. The neutron + helium-3 scattering length strongly depends on the relative directions that the neutron and nucleus are spinning, an important consideration in theoretical models. Our experiment required a selection of the spin direction of both the neutron and helium-3 gas, which was quite difficult. In fact this was the first and, so far, only use of a spin-polarized target in a neutron interferometer.

 

Our result [1] is presented in the attached figure. The horizontal axis is the scattering length for the case where the neutron and helium-3 spins sum to zero (singlet) and the vertical axis is the case where they sum to 1 unit of Plank's constant (triplet). The blue diagonal bar is the range of our measurement and the red bar is a previous experiment by Zimmer, et al. [2] at the ILL (Grenoble, France) that used a very different method. They agree quite well. The black circle, diamond, and square are theoretical estimates by Hofmann and Hale that utilize different models of the nuclear force [3].  These measurements help determine the details of nuclear interactions.

 

 

[1] M. G. Huber, et al., Physical Review C, Vol. 90, 064004 (2014).

[2] O. Zimmer, et al., European Physics Journal Direct, Vol. 4, 1, (2002).

[3] H. M. Hofmann and G. M. Hale, Physical Review C, Vol. 68, 021002 (2003).
